Situation1: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story: I was scrubbing the bathroom tiles, the smell of bleach stinging my nose, when I noticed a small, velvet pouch tucked behind the toilet. Curiosity got the better of me, and I peeked inside—there was a gold bracelet, clearly valuable, and a folded note with a name I didn’t recognize. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Deep clean every room, check every corner, and report anything unusual.” I knew I was supposed to hand over anything I found, no questions asked. But as a Christian, I remembered the teachings about honesty and doing what’s right, not just what’s required. What if this belonged to a guest who desperately needed it back? What if reporting it meant it would never be returned to its rightful owner? My hands trembled as I held the pouch, torn between following my job’s strict protocol and listening to the quiet voice inside urging me to act with compassion and integrity. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I stood frozen, unsure which path to take.
